docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''9 Million Gaining Upgraded Benefit for Mental Care'' (front page, Jan. 1): Treating the so-called worried well is not expensive, as claimed by the insurance industry, when you are heading off stresses that can drive cardiovascular disease, asthma attacks, some cancers and other conditions requiring costly hospital stays.
docs.abstract: Nancy Brach letter, commenting on Jan 1 article, says treating so-called worried well may head off stresses that contribute to illnesses; says significant economies may be produced through parity for addiction diseases

docs.lead_paragraph: A 13-hour negotiating session mediated by a United States senator brought a tentative agreement early yesterday in the Pacific Northwest Newspaper Guild's increasingly bitter and costly 45-day strike against The Seattle Times. A ratification vote is expected this weekend, a union spokesman said.

headline.main: Tentative Deal Is Reached In Seattle Newspaper Strike

docs.abstract: Thirteen-hour negotiating session mediated by Sen Patty Murray of Washington State brings tentative agreement in Pacific Northwest Newspaper Guild's increasingly bitter and costly 45-day strike against The Seattle Times; photo (M)
docs.snippet: A 13-hour negotiating session mediated by a United States senator brought a tentative agreement early yesterday in the Pacific Northwest Newspaper Guild's increasingly bitter and costly 45-day strike against The Seattle Times.    A ratification vote...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: President Clinton's executive order to give federal employees mental health benefits equal to those for other medical ailments (front page, Jan. 1) is a victory for millions with mental illnesses and for the individuals and organizations that have fought for parity. This advocacy has been based on state experience with parity and on data documenting the minimal increase in cost. The benefits of higher productivity, decreased absenteeism and decreased disability claims also helped make the case.
docs.abstract: Dr Daniel B Borenstein letter lauds Pres Clinton's exec order to give federal employees mental health benefits equal to those for other medical ailments

docs.lead_paragraph: Six years after promising to change the ways of Washington fundamentally, House Republicans today made good on their pledge to curtail the power of committee barons and replaced 13 of their most senior chairmen. The newly created selection process created fierce competition among members who sought the positions, intensified party fund-raising by the members seeking to demonstrate loyalty and led to the creation of a new committee.

headline.main: HONORING '95 VOW, HOUSE REPUBLICANS REPLACE 13 CHIEFS

docs.abstract: House Republicans honor their 1995 vow to curtail power of committee barons, replacing 13 of their most senior chairmen; newly created selection process creates fierce competition among members who seek positions, intensifies party fund-raising by members seeking to demonstrate loyalty and leads to creation of new committee; Rep Bill Thomas of California is named chairman of powerful Ways and Means Committee; Rep Henry J Hyde will give up chairmanship of Judiciary Committee to head International Relations Committee; sweep of committee chairmanships goes further than any other turnover could, and carries repercussions for industry lobbyists, who have spent years building relationships with former chairmen; committee chairmen can use their posts to help shape policy, often dictating success or failure of legislation; new chairmen were chosen by steering committee made up of Speaker J Dennis Hastert, majority leader, Rep Dick Armey, along with chairmen of several committes and representatives from each region; photos; chart listing new chairmen (M)
docs.snippet: Six years after promising to change the ways of Washington fundamentally, House Republicans today made good on their pledge to curtail the power of committee barons and replaced 13 of their most senior chairmen.    The newly created selection process...

keywords.value: SENATE COMMITTEE ON WAYS AND MEANS

docs.lead_paragraph: The patients at the Anchorage Native Primary Care Center, a medical clinic in Alaska, did not like to wait. And yet waiting, it seemed, was almost all they did. It took a month or longer to see a doctor. And when patients arrived at the clinic, they usually waited an hour or more to get into an examining room. While their health care at the clinic cost them nothing -- they are Native Americans, using a facility that was partly financed by the federal government -- the delays were so onerous that those who could afford to get their health care elsewhere did so.

headline.main: Harried Doctors Try to Ease Big Delays and Rushed Visits

docs.abstract: Innovations spurred by clinic doctors to end long waits for appointments, jammed waiting rooms and rushed visits are being shown to alleviate irritation felt by doctors and patients and save money; include new scheduling methods, group office visits for up to two dozen people, scheduled phone calls from doctor in lieu of clinic visits for patients with chronic diseases that require vigilance and giving patients online access to their medical records; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: John Fraser, a 47-year-old cabdriver, is worried about the economy. The holiday season ''is usually really busy, but this year the days have been a bit quiet,'' he lamented.

headline.main: Reading Tea Leaves In the Taxis Of London

docs.abstract: Sales of new taxis in London have once again begun to stall; people in industry say rise and fall of cab industry has in past acted as bellwether for broader economy, with sharp downturn preceding last recession, in early 1990's; photos (M)
docs.snippet: John Fraser, a 47-year-old cabdriver, is worried about the economy.    The holiday season ''is usually really busy, but this year the days have been a bit quiet,'' he lamented.

docs.lead_paragraph: The juxtaposition of economic activities yesterday was striking. In Austin, Tex., a hand-picked bunch of corporate chief executives sat around with President-elect George W. Bush discussing the need for tax cuts and interest rate reductions. But while they talked, Alan Greenspan and the Federal Reserve in Washington took bold and carefully calibrated action to stimulate the economy. The Fed's decision to cut a key short-term interest rate, timed to counteract a recent plunge in consumer confidence and poor earnings reports, provided powerful evidence that the nimble Fed can do far more to combat the economic slowdown through monetary policy than the incoming Bush administration can hope to achieve through its enormous proposed tax cut. Mr. Bush tried gamely yesterday to argue that the Fed's recognition that the economy is in trouble actually underscored the need to go ahead with his tax cut as well. But that rationale seemed increasingly dubious given that the proposed 10-year, $1.3 trillion tax cut -- actually $1.9 trillion, when interest costs are factored into the estimate -- with cuts backloaded to the later years, would not take hold for quite some time, perhaps well after any stimulus is needed.
docs.abstract: Editorial hails dramatic Federal Reserve cut in key interest rate, timed to counteract recent plunge in consumer confidence and poor earnings reports; holds nimble Fed can do far more to combat economic slowdown through monetary policy than incoming Bush administration can achieve through its enormous proposed tax cut; notes tax cut stimulus might not be felt until well after it is needed

headline.main: Testing 1, 2, 3: My Brush With Managed Care

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. George E. Pataki used his annual address to the Legislature today to call on lawmakers to streamline the way the state pays for education, to give local districts much more control over how they spend such aid. Apparently laying the groundwork for a campaign for a third term, the governor, in his hourlong address, promoted a laundry list of proposals, including the use of public money to promote high-tech industries, cuts in property taxes for farmers and the elderly, and a revamping of the Rockefeller drug laws.

headline.main: Pataki Calls for Local Control Of Most State Aid to Schools

docs.abstract: Gov George E Pataki, in State of State Message, calls for consolidating most New York State aid to local school districts into single grant to give districts much more control over how they spend aid; says larger share of aid should go to New York City and other high needs districts; promotes laundry list of proposals, including use of public money to spur biotechnology industries, cuts in property taxes for farmers and elderly, and revamping of Rockefeller drug laws, in what many legislators see as opening salvo in expected re-election drive; calls for bipartisan cooperation; Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver charges Pataki hides behind cloak of reform while threatening to cut funds for needed school programs; Sen Joseph L Bruno backs simplification of aid formulas, but warns move would be politically tricky; Comptroller H Carl McCall, who weighs run for governor, scores speech (M)
